Award.AwardTitle: Receiver function based on dense arrays
Award.AbstractNarration:
To understand the dynamics of Earth's interior and predict ground motions during large earthquakes, seismologists use waves emitted from earthquakes to image structures of the Earth. The traditional receiver function method, which uses medium-size earthquakes thousands of kilometers away as sources, is a popular tool in studying receiver-side discontinuities and depth of sedimentary basins. This research aims to develop a new receiver function method that can take advantage of the rise of dense seismic arrays with hundreds or even thousands of sensors, to produce more detailed and reliable images of the Earth.

The new receiver-function methodology aims to overcome the limitations introduced by deconvolution at individual stations, by inverting for full receiver function images directly from the waveforms recorded along a dense profile. This approach will produce higher-resolution images because it makes better use of available data and enhances coherent conversions. The researchers will test this new method with available data to image subduction zones in Middle and South America that can generate large or even mega-thrust earthquakes. Additionally, the method will be applied to data collected in a densely populated basin in southern California to better characterize possible ground motions during future large earthquakes.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Receiver function is an important seismological method for imaging sharp structures inside Earth, such as bases of sedimentary basins and the top of subducted oceanic plates. These sharp structures are often critical for understanding where earthquakes could happen and how strong/long the ground shaking will be in future events. Conventional receiver function method is station by station, without considering the relations between stations because they were usually far apart. However, in the last decade, new types of seismic arrays using relative low-cost geophones (i.e., nodes) started to become so dense that nearby stations sample largely overlapped subsurface structures. This presents a unique opportunity to improve the receiver function method by taking into account the overlapping sensitivities. The improvement will also partially compensate the relative short duration of nodal deployment, constrained by battery life. 

The Coherent Receiver Function (CRF) method we developed under the NSF award 1722879 successfully achieved the goal. The CRF software package we developed groups data from neighboring seismic stations to estimate a receiver function profile that is simple and sharp yet still explains all the data as well as in convention receiver functions. Due to the joint inversion of grouped data, the CRF images usually have much less artifacts and even works when only a few earthquakes are available during short nodal deployments. We tested our data with both synthetic and real data and concluded a robust performance.  

While we expect the CRF method to be widely useful in regional seismology, for this project we applied it to two important science questions as a proof of concept. The first one is sedimentary basins in the greater Los Angeles region. The depth and geometry of sedimentary basins strongly affect the shaking intensity and durations during earthquakes, but are still poorly constrained around the world, including the Los Angeles region. Conventional receiver functions derived from a recent nodal seismic deployment had limited quality due to the relatively small number of usable teleseismic earthquakes in noisy urban areas within only 1 month of data. Using the same dataset, our CRF profiles instead show the basin bottom clearly with realistic uncertainty estimates. This result suggests that the CRF method can be a powerful tool in mapping urban basins in the future for earthquake hazard purposes. 

The second application of the CRF method is in the Cascadia subduction zone, where magnitude 9 earthquakes are known to have striked in the past. The properties of the plate interface, on which the M9 earthquakes happened, are critical for predicting the extent of the future large earthquakes. Multiple dense seismic profiles have been deployed in the past, including one that had a broadband survey in the 1990s and another nodal seismic survey in the 2010s. However, there are still substantial discrepancies between the results that previous studies could not reconcile. Due to the data group capabilities of our CRF method, we are able to jointly invert the broadband data from the 1990s and the nodal seismic data in the 2010s for a unified, higher-resolution model. We found that the mechanical properties of the oceanic crust along the profile are actually laterally variable, potentially caused by dehydration processes. Similar applications of the CRF method may help reveal other fine-scale structures in the Cascadia and other subduction zones. 

In summary, we have successfully developed a new receiver function method that fits the needs of modern dense seismic arrays and provides high-resolution images of the Earth interior. Applications so far show promising results. This software package is being distributed among the seismological community to ensure the maximum impact.
